title: 106_hr2845
content: The Act titled "21st Century Teacher Training Act of 1999" provides grants for classroom-related computer training for teachers. The Secretary of Education may award grants to local educational agencies for classroom-related computer training for teachers, with a minimum grant amount of $10,000,000. Grant recipients must enter into a contract with an educational provider for the training. The Secretary of Education may award grants to local educational agencies for teacher training programs. The contractor will establish, operate, and provide the non-Federal share of the program's cost. Funds from the Secretary will cover the Federal share of the cost. Grantees must meet conditions and standards set by the Secretary for compliance. Teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will be conducted year-round, train teachers from kindergarten to college, select teachers for a teacher network to conduct workshops, and encourage teachers from all disciplines to participate. Grants awarded under this section must supplement, not supplant, State and local funds for the specified purpose. SEC. 3. INCOME TAX CREDIT FOR TECHNOLOGY-RELATED PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS. An amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include a new section allowing for technology-related professional development expenses of teachers. An income tax credit is allowed for eligible teachers for qualified technology-related expenses up to $1,000 per year. Eligible teachers are defined as full-time K-12 teachers in the US or those expecting to be in the upcoming academic year. For eligible teachers, a tax credit is available for qualified technology-related expenses, including training in technology use in the classroom and the cost of computers or technology equipment. No double benefit deduction is allowed. No deduction allowed for expenses if a credit is claimed. Taxpayers can choose to not apply the credit for a taxable year. Section 25B allows for technology-related professional development expenses of teachers. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Section 4 expands the deduction for computer donations to schools and public libraries. Expansion of Computer Donations to Public Libraries by amending the Internal Revenue Code to allow for qualified computer contributions instead of qualified elementary or secondary educational contributions. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for qualified computer contributions to public libraries, expanding the scope beyond elementary or secondary educational contributions. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the definition of qualified educational contributions to include qualified computer contributions to public libraries. The changes include extending the time period from 2 years to 3 years and specifying conditions for when the taxpayer acquired or reacquired the property, when construction is completed, or when the property was originally obtained. The amendment extends qualified educational contributions to include computer donations to public libraries. It specifies conditions for when the taxpayer acquired or reacquired the property and applies to contributions made after the enactment of the Act. The amendment adds a new credit for computer donations to schools and public libraries under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment introduces a tax credit for computer donations to schools and public libraries. The credit is 30% of qualified contributions, but increases to 50% for donations to organizations in designated zones or Indian reservations. There is a limitation on the credit for computer contributions with specific software. The section discusses the requirements for a qualified computer contribution for tax purposes, including the definition of computer software and the application of certain rules. It also specifies that the section will not apply after three years from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, amendments are made to the current year business credit calculation in the tax code. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding the disallowance of deductions by the amount of credit for school and public library computer donations. This includes defining qualified computer contributions and specifying that no deduction is allowed for the amount of credit determined under section 45D(a). Amendments to the tax code disallow deductions by the amount of credit for school and public library computer donations. No carryback of school and public library computer donation credit is allowed before the effective date. The amendments disallow deductions for school and public library computer donations. The credit for computer donations to schools and public libraries applies to contributions made in taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
